Just registered [Ueauty](<https://gitlab.com/ExpandingMan/Ueauty.jl>) for simple, universally recognized unicode aliases with zero package dependencies.  My evil plan is to make the remaining "blindingly obvious" unicode aliases that are not in `Base` so common that nobody will be able to argue against putting them in `Base`
```using Ueauty; @ueauty

# Integer abstract type
f(n::‚Ñ§) = n + 1

# Real abstract type, summation with \sum (distinct from \Sigma)
g(v::Vector{<:‚Ñù}) = ‚àë(v)

# Complex abstract type, product with \prod (distinct from \Pi)
h(v::Vector{<:‚ÑÇ}) = ‚àè(v)

# \infty for floating point Inf
typemax(Float64) == ‚àû 

# \scri for the imaginary unit
‚ÑØ^(ùíæ*œÄ) ‚âà -1.0

# \Rightarrow for pairs
Dict(:a‚áí1, :b‚áí2)

# \triangleright for |> pipe operator
rand(5) ‚ñ∑ ‚àë ‚ñ∑ sinh```

text:
This package is eye candy, but I'm a little concerned about the impact a package would have to accessibility of Julia.
‚Ä¢ A person has to fix a Julia script in using Nano on some server and can't type unicode characters. What happens if Unicode is now rampant across the Julia ecosystem?
‚Ä¢ People have to have a math degree - or at least math university education to get what `foo(::‚Ñ§)` means. This kind of advanced mathematical notation is not clear unless you've studied it
‚Ä¢ I wouldn't be comfortable forcing people to use a font that is able to display all sorts of Unicode characters in order to be able to use Julia

Point by point:
- It's already pretty common, and there are already a ton of aliases in `Base`.  All editor that are at all likely to be used for coding have the capability to do latex to unicode, though you are right about cases where people don't have the plugin.
- I completely reject that notion.  For one thing, high school students and first year undergards are asked to deal with that notation all the time, but that's besides the point.  If you see it the first time, it's unexpected, but then you quickly learn what it means and move on, that's just life.  After all they are just some aliases, you don't need to have a real grasp on the axioms of the real numbers to use a Julia `Real`.
- I would agree with you here if I felt this was really the case, but fortunately the majority of monospace fonts are good enough to be legible.  There's nothing here that's likely to "totally break" on a "normal" setup.  Same goes for the stuff that's already in `Base` of course.  Yes, JuliaMono is better, but by no means do you get gibberish if you don't use this.  I agree this is a valid concern, and I *would* consider it if adding any new aliases.

<@U7HAYKY9X> As a devil's advocate I'll retort with
‚Ä¢ I'm pretty sure that this is not an issue-- I'm pretty sure unicode encoding happens at the client and is sent across the wire. I mean, a default installation of nano doesn't have that any facilities for backslash-tab-completion, but it does have copy-paste.
‚Ä¢ Definitely doesn't take a math degree to parse the sentence "‚Ñ§ is the integers".
‚Ä¢ This is kind of like the 80-column terminal support argument which Linus Torvalds recently admonished people for, and I think the resolution is the same-- it's 2021 and this maybe isn't a demographic we should be designing our code for.
